answers.author: William Emerson
answers.text:
We budget a contingency appropriation in the General Fund of at least 5% and no more than 10% of that year’s budgeted expenditures, and an Operational Reserve of at least 30% and no more than 50% of the average actual General Fund revenues for the preceding 5 fiscal years.   Operational Reserve may only be used to cover unforeseen emergencies and unexpected declines in revenue. To the extent these reserves are expended, the Town will increase its General Fund revenues or decrease its expenditures as necessary to prevent the continued use of these reserves.  Additional funds necessary to restore this Operational Reserve amount will be provided in approximately equal contributions during the 3 fiscal years following the fiscal year in which the drawdown of the reserve occurred.
Our GF Reserve policy is found at http://www.dhaz.gov/images/stories/pdfs/finance/The%20Appendices.pdf, at page 92; but we are updating this policy in light of GFOA's "The New Fund Balance" and GASB No. 54.

Below is Howard, Wisconsin's General Fund Reserve Policy:
The General Fund policy for fund balance reserve was modified by the Village Board in 2007.  The new policy establishes the fund balance to be between 25%-40% of the previous year’s actual expenditures within the fund.  All excess funds above this policy are transferred from the General Fund into a capital project fund titled Redevelopment Fund in 2007.

answers.author: Matthew McQuillen
answers.text:
Don, our council has a budget policy that stipulates we keep a minimum cash balance reserve of 20% in the general fund when compared to general fund expenditures.  We actually try to adhere to that policy for all of our "operational" funds (Road Use, Utilities).  The main reason for the policy is to keep the bond rating companies happy since we are a growing community and issue significant amounts of debt on a regular basis.  I have forwarded our budget policy to Lexington.

answers.author: Catheryn Whitesell
answers.text:
In Virginia Beach our policy is to keep the undesignated balance between 8% and 12% of the next year's General Fund Revenues with a Council established target of 10%. All end year funds revert to the General Fund balance prior to reappropriation to ensure that we maintain the policy. City Council is notified of any use of fund balance and its impact on the Fund Balance policy. A projection of the fund balance is included in the proposed budget. By City Council policy fund balance can only be used for one time purposes unless exempted by them.

answers.author: Roderick Wood
answers.text:
I consider a 10% reserve a minimum.  In my opinion how much reserve you should maintain depends on the volatility of your revenue sources and the rigidity of your expenses.  The more volatile the sources like sales taxes, and the more rigid your expenses like debt service, the larger the reserve.  In my last city we maintained a 40% reserve because 80% of our revenues were highly volatile.  the level of reserves should not be affected by how flush or poor the budget is, but it may well take years to build an adequate reserve if you are a community of modest budget resources.  Your reserve requirements should be included in your formal financial policies.

answers.author: Reyna Farrales
answers.text:
Our Board (San Mateo County, CA) adopted updates to our Reserves Policy in February 2010. Our Budget Director led a cross-departmental workgroup of fiscal officers that conducted a survey of 18 counties and 5 cities in California as part of this effort. Minimum General Fund reserves requirement was increased to 10% of Net Appropriations, plus $2 million for capital projects and $2 million for technology projects. The policy covers appropriate uses of Departmental and Non-Departmental Reserves. When Reserves exceed minimum requirements, allowable uses include cost avoidance and productivity enhancement projects, debt retirement, seed money for pilot programs, and innovation and entrepreneurial fund. I've attached the policy and e-mailed to Lexington.

answers.author: James Ley
answers.text:
I have attached the Sarasota reserve policy.  Many fators influenced the development of this policy.  First and foremost we are susceptible to hurricanes, and so our emergency reserve is pretty hefty.  But, having been through several recessions, this one proving the point, we also established a stabalization reserve and have been living off of this and a series of management actions for the last two years.  You can see that the reseve policy also addresses other dimensions of county operations from our enterprise funds to compensated absences.  If anyone is interested in a narative history of how we moved the County Commission conversaation over eight years and how we now use this policy as the centerpiece of a multiple year budget strategy you can contact me at jley@scgov.net
Jim Ley

author: Donald Gloo
text:
I am posting this question on behalf of a city in Kentucky.
How does your organization determine the target amount for your General Fund Reserve? Is it a % of the GF budget?
What mechanism(s) does your organization use to increase your GF Reserve balance when it is short of the target?
Does your organization have a written policy for determining when the GF Reserve can--or cannot--be tapped?
If possible, please send a copy of your policy language to twilson@lexingtonky.gov.
Thanks!
